article.title: Expectations for the muon g-2 in simplified models with dark matter

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the dark blue region in Figure 5(a) represent?
choices: Parameter space allowed at 2σ by the relic density.
Parameter space favored by the (g − 2)µ measurement.
Parameter space where both relic density and (g − 2)µ constraints are satisfied.
Parameter space where Ωh² ≈ 0.12 is due to the bulk mechanism.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 5(b), what does the gray triangle region represent?
choices: Parameter space excluded by the CMS 2 soft leptons search.
Parameter space excluded by the ATLAS 2 hard leptons search.
Parameter space favored by both relic density and (g − 2)µ.
Parameter space where the relic density is dominated by the bulk mechanism.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 5(c), what is the projected reach of future precision experiments on the surviving parameter space?
choices: They can probe the entire surviving region.
They have limited reach and will not be able to test most of the surviving region.
They will only be able to probe the region with YS > 2.
They are not expected to improve on the current constraints.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main limitation of the monojet search in probing the surviving parameter space in Figure 5(b)?
choices: The mass difference between the fermion and the dark matter scalar is too large.
The portal Higgs coupling is too small.
The monojet search is only sensitive to doublet scalar dark matter.
The monojet search is not sensitive enough to probe this region.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the horizontal red solid line in Figure 6 represent?
choices: The 2σ region of the Fermilab experiment.
The upper limit on the new Yukawa coupling from perturbativity.
The lower limit on the new Yukawa coupling from the relic density.
The 2σ region of the BNL experiment.

multiple_choice_question.text: What happens to the allowed parameter space in Model 1 when the mass of the VL fermion increases?
choices: The allowed range of the new Yukawa coupling increases.
The allowed range of the new Yukawa coupling decreases.
The allowed range of the scalar dark matter mass increases.
The allowed range of the scalar dark matter mass decreases.

multiple_choice_question.text: Why is there a lower limit on the scalar dark matter mass in Model 1?
choices: The bulk mechanism loses efficiency when the mass splitting between ms and mE is significant.
The LHC excludes dark matter masses below ~40 GeV.
Direct detection experiments exclude dark matter masses below ~50 GeV.
The (g − 2)µ constraint requires a minimum dark matter mass.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 6 suggest about the perturbativity of the new Yukawa coupling, YS, in Model 1?
choices: It remains perturbative up to the Planck scale for all allowed values.
It can become non-perturbative below the Planck scale for large values of YS.
Perturbativity is not a concern in this model.
The figure does not provide information about perturbativity.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 7(a), what does the darker shade of cyan in the relic density region represent?
choices: Parameter space where the relic abundance is dominated by the Higgs portal.
Parameter space where Ωh² ≈ 0.12 is due to the bulk mechanism.
Parameter space allowed at 2σ by the (g − 2)µ measurement.
Parameter space excluded by electroweak precision observables.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 7(b), what constraint primarily excludes points with large fermion masses?
choices: LHC searches for 2-lepton + missing ET signature.
Electroweak precision observables (EWPOs).
Direct detection experiments.
Constraints from the branching ratio BR(h → γγ).

multiple_choice_question.text: Which future experiment has the potential to probe the points marked as black triangles in Figure 7(b)?
choices: LHC with increased luminosity.
XENON-IT with new data.
Future precision experiments like TLEP.
None of the above.

multiple_choice_question.text: Why do the points marked as red squares in Figure 7(b) appear to be beyond the reach of foreseeable experiments?
choices: They are characterized by a very small Yukawa coupling.
They are characterized by a very large Yukawa coupling.
The scalar and lightest fermion mass are very close to each other.
The scalar and lightest fermion mass are very far apart.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the most significant difference between Model 1a (Figure 8(a)) and Model 1 (Figure 5(a)) with respect to the (g − 2)µ anomaly?
choices: Model 1a requires a larger Yukawa coupling to accommodate the anomaly.
Model 1a can accommodate the anomaly with a lighter dark matter mass.
Model 1a is more constrained by LHC searches.
Model 1a is more constrained by direct detection experiments.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary reason for the exclusion of the gray region in Figure 8(b)?
choices: Constraints from the branching ratio BR(h → γγ).
Electroweak precision observables.
Direct detection experiments.
LHC searches for 2-lepton + missing ET signature.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the dashed lines in Figure 8(b)?
choices: They represent the projected reach of future precision experiments at GigaZ and TLEP.
They represent the projected reach of the ATLAS search with 300 fb−¹.
They represent the boundary of the parameter space where perturbativity breaks down.
They represent the boundary of the parameter space where the relic density is dominated by the bulk mechanism.

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of solutions are featured in the region with good dark matter in Figure 8(a)?
choices: Only solutions with degenerate scalar masses (ms ≈ ma).
Only solutions with one scalar mass much heavier than the other (ms  ma or ma  ms).
Solutions of various types, including ms ≈ ma, ms  ma, ma  ms, and cases in between.
None of the above.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 9(a), what happens to the dark matter abundance as mDM approaches mE?
choices: It becomes over-abundant.
It becomes under-abundant.
It remains constant.
The figure does not provide information about the dark matter abundance.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary difference between the two cases shown in Figure 9(a) and Figure 9(b)?
choices: The type of VL fermion involved (singlet vs. doublet).
The mass difference between the scalar and pseudoscalar dark matter particles.
The value of the Yukawa coupling to the muon.
The impact of LHC constraints.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 9(b), which scenario resembles the behavior of Model 1?
choices: The case where ms ≈ ma.
The case where ms  ma.
The case where ma  ms.
None of the above.

multiple_choice_question.text: What happens to the efficiency of the bulk mechanism as ms ≈ ma approaches mE in Figure 9(a)?
choices: It decreases.
It increases.
It remains constant.
The figure does not provide information about the efficiency of the bulk mechanism.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main difference in the allowed dark matter mass range between models with a complex scalar singlet and those with a doublet scalar?
choices: Models with a complex scalar singlet can have much lighter dark matter.
Models with a doublet scalar can have much lighter dark matter.
Both types of models have the same allowed dark matter mass range.
The figure does not provide information about the allowed dark matter mass range.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 10(b), why is (g − 2)µ generally smaller than in Model 4 (Figure 10(a)) for the equivalent parameter range?
choices: The doublet VL fermion has a smaller Yukawa coupling to the muon.
There is a negative contribution from the charged scalar/neutral fermion loop.
The mass of the VL fermion is larger in Model 5.
The LHC constraints are stronger in Model 5.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which model in Figure 10 only allows for simultaneous solutions to the (g − 2)µ anomaly and dark matter in the Higgs-resonance region?
choices: Model 4 (doublet scalar and singlet VL fermions)
Model 5 (doublet scalar and doublet VL fermions)
Model 7 (doublet scalar and triplet VL fermions)
Model 8 (doublet scalar and adjoint triplet VL fermions)

multiple_choice_question.text: Why is there no parameter space in Model 8 (Figure 10(d)) that can accommodate both the measured value of (g − 2)µ and the relic density?
choices: The new Yukawa coupling, YA, must be too small to satisfy Ωh² ≈ 0.12.
The VL fermion mass must be too large to accommodate (g − 2)µ.
The LHC constraints are too strong in this model.
The Higgs-resonance region does not provide a viable solution in this model.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the compressed region in Figure 11 represent?
choices: Parameter space where the masses of the charged fermion and dark matter are very different.
Parameter space where the masses of the charged fermion and dark matter are almost degenerate.
Parameter space excluded by the LHC 2-lepton searches.
Parameter space where the relic density is dominated by the Higgs portal mechanism.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which LHC search is most effective in testing the compressed region in Figure 11?
choices: ATLAS 2-lepton + missing ET search.
CMS 2 soft leptons + missing ET search.
Monojet search.
Higgs invisible decay search.

multiple_choice_question.text: What happens to the mass of the charged VL fermions outside of the compressed region in Figure 11?
choices: It decreases.
It increases.
It remains constant.
The figure does not provide information about the mass of the charged VL fermions.

multiple_choice_question.text: Why is the lower bound on the fermion mass in Model 4 weaker than the corresponding bound for Model 1?
choices: Model 4 has a larger Yukawa coupling to the muon.
The decay E → S⁺ν¯µ is possible in Model 4.
The LHC constraints are weaker in Model 4.
The relic density constraint is stronger in Model 4.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the orange dotted line in Figure 12 represent?
choices: Singlet VL fermions
Doublet VL fermions
Triplet VL fermions
Adjoint triplet VL fermions

multiple_choice_question.text: Why does δ (g − 2)µ  drop in the Higgs-resonance region in Figure 12?
choices: The charged fermion mass is progressively pushed to larger values.
The Yukawa coupling to the muon is suppressed.
The relic density constraint becomes stronger.
The LHC constraints become stronger.

multiple_choice_question.text: In which model does the Yukawa coupling need to be significantly reduced in the Higgs resonance to achieve Ωh² ≈ 0.12 and bring δ (g − 2)µ back into the allowed region?
choices: Model 4 (Gray solid line)
Model 5 (Magenta dashed line)
Model 7 (Blue dot-dashed line)
Model 8 (Orange dotted line)

multiple_choice_question.text: Why is there no common parameter space for (g − 2)µ and dark matter in the Higgs-resonance region for Model 5 (magenta dashed line)?
choices: The Yukawa coupling is too small in the Higgs resonance to accommodate (g − 2)µ.
The VL fermion mass is too large in the Higgs resonance to accommodate (g − 2)µ.
Both A and B are correct.
Neither A nor B is correct.
